content:
Amended the typo in the first test case ("Example" instead of "Exemple").
Removed unnecessary trailing spaces/lines in the first test case and first validator.

Nice one !

Just a small issue : the first sample (and corresponding validator) have trailing spaces at the first line, which breaks the C++ template (first circuit line becomes the white space end of height + width line).

I have already approved this, but after the fact it occurred to me that the validators are sufficiently different from the test cases that many people might run into problems with tests passing but validators failing. I can't think of a specific bug that would cause this, but that hasn't stopped it from happening in the past. :-)

This puzzle has a couple of pretty simple solutions. I'd recommend one of the following:

 - Make each validator a mirror image of the corresponding test
 - Make each validator the same as the corresponding test with all inputs and switches toggled

In either case, you can make the current validators into new tests if you're particularly fond of them. :-)

Very nice puzzle. I greatly enjoyed solving it. Thank you. Here are a few comments:

 - Stub generator for width height is wrong. The values are on a single line, so it should be:

read height:int width:int

 - Several instances of "lit up a LED", "lit the LED", etc. should all be changed to "light the LED", etc.

 - "Magnificient" should be spelled as "Magnificent"

I have made these changes myself, and will approve the puzzle shortly.

Not started yet. Looks cool, I'll definitely give it a go.

First impressions from reading the statement only:
- switches behave significantly different from gates. The first example would greatly benefit from featuring one, to provide a visual impression (half of the puzzle *is* graphical recognition)
(- by the way, from an electronics point of view, it feels a bit weird to feature switches at the same level as gates.)
- the constraints kind of make it obvious brute force enumeration is expected. But there's already a serious puzzle just with the chart recognition, it wouldn't be easy to split.
- the shared characters are quite unfortunate. They make human recognition harder, and restrict the possibilities for solving the recognition part of the problem. Could you consider e.g. A, O, X for AND OR XOR, a, o, x for NAND NOR XNOR?
- the constraints could use a liitle nudge in the lines of "planar circuit; no loops"

I kinda pity those whose languages can not eval/compile dynamic expressions/code. My js solution is 7 times shorter than yours.

Nice puzzle though. A bit too brute-force-ish perhaps, I feel like there might be some tricks and analysis possible that can allow smarter solutions to work for much more complex test cases... On the other hand, maybe it's better to not fry people's brains completely :p

"input and output pins are always represented as a - and ..."
you mean "as a |"

Hi there,

Another puzzle based on file reading, logic and signal propagation (sort of).

Please give me comments.

Thanks

Like asked on your Syllogisms puzzle, a formatting like :

Line 1 : L H (or H L) for the length and height of the given map
[[H]] next lines : Line by line, the map

would be more suitable on this puzzle.
well spotted, I fix this right away

Thanks for your feedback.

I'm sure there are smarter ways to do it

"wires do not overlap each other nor do they go thru/above/under a gate", so last point is done already.

using different symbols would make it a bit easier, yes, but then again you can do that yourself with 1 regex replace... so i dont mind sticking with the current notation, especially if it's used as such in other literature and was not invented for this puzzle. not sure if it is though. 0-0=1?  if the current symbols for the not-ops are not really standard, i could even see using two chars for them (~& ~| ~+)

I tried to made it so that the validators validate the same feature that is introduced in the matching tests:

- test / validotr #1 : basic AND and OR gates. I have just exchanged the OR and AND gates from the test.  Otherwise the cabling/wiring is exactly the same

- test / validator #2 : introduction of the NOT gate. Again same layout but gates are different. So there should be no diffrence in coding / difficulty

- test / validator #3 :  introduction of wires' forking. Here indead the layouts are completly differents, but still no new features.

- test / validator #4 : introduction of switches. No wire forking here. But in validator the switch is inversed. Alsothe layout is different, but then people shouldn't have any problem at this stage.

- test / validator #5 : introduction of inverted gates (XNOR, NOR and NAND). Otherwise no new concepts

- test / validator #6 : no new features, just a big layout with all features.

But I agree I should add more tests/validators to introduce the gates a couple at a time. Maybe like this;

#1 : AND
#2: OR
#3 : mix of AND and OR
#4 : NOT
#5 : NAND and NOR
#6 : XOR and XNOR
#8 : switches
#7: wire forking
#9 : complex layout (wire forking, switches, many gates)

What do you reckon ?

I've edited the puzzle just now:

Goal
* Changed "a LED" to "an LED".
* Changed "thru" to "through".
* Deleted "of course" and "of courses".
* Changed "a minimum steps" to "minimum steps".
* Capitalised the first letter of each of the points under the CMOS format, and replaced the ending semicolon with a full-stop.
* Added "are given first, followed by the circuit itself".
* Changed "file" to "circuit" for points 2 and 3 of the CMOS format.
* Changed "at the last useful line" to "on the last line".
* Changed "{{[]}}" to "{{[}} and {{]}}".
* Changed "maybe" to "may be".
* Changed "each input and outputs" to "inputs and outputs".

Input
* Formatted the line numbers in <<bold>>.
* Fixed the typo "eletronic" twice.
* Changed "[[height]] [[width]] height and width of the the layout of the eletronic circuit space separated" to "Two space-separated integers [[height]] and [[width]] for the height and width of the layout of the electronic circuit".
* Changed "{{[]}}" to "{{[}} and {{]}}".
* Changed "{{-|+}}" to "{{-}}, {{|}} and {{+}}".

Output
* Changed "You must output the" to "<<A number of lines>>: The".
* Changed "Each step must be on a line" to "one step per line".

Constraints
* Replaced all "<=" and "<" with "≤".
* Changed the lower limit of height and width from 0 to 1.
* Changed the upper limit of height and width from 127 to 50.
* Removed the variable formatting for "number of switches" and "number of inputs".

Tags
* Added "Logic".

I will never argue with more tests. :-) That being said, I think that what you have is probably good enough. I'm just recommending that you make the validators more like the associated tests. It's not a strong recommendation. Just something that I see as an opportunity. If you'd prefer not to, that's just fine.

As an example, "Fork ?" and "Fork !" are very different from each other. The validator could be written instead as a mirror of the test like so:

`
         [@]         
          |          
         [~]         
          |          
        [ | ]        
         | |         
      +--+ +--+      
      |       |      
    [ | ]   [ | ]    
     | |     | |     
  +--+ +--+--+ +--+  
  |       |       |  
[ & ]   [ & ]   [ | ]
 | |     | |     | | 
 | +--+--+ +--+--+ | 
 |    |       |    | 
[~] [ | ]   [ & ] [~]
 |   | |     | |   | 
 0   0 1     1 1   0 
`

Remember, the validators are simply there to ensure that the user has successfully solved the concepts introduced in the tests. The CG populace, in general, spends a lot of time debugging failed validators. The simpler the validators (while still doing verification) the better.

 Just my 2¢.

 - danBhentschel

EDIT: Ack! Formatting! Hopefully you get the idea. :-)

Good point for the planes/loops, thanks for spotting.

My point wrt ASCII is not "it's hard", my point is "it's restrictive".
I'm aware of the literature. It only supports &. I'm also aware it doesn't mix gates and switches as such.
There's a balance to be struck between having beauty, consistency, and a fun puzzle. IMHO the current graphics hinder beauty and fun at an attempt at consistency I'd personally qualify as misguided (| for OR is CS, not EE, and it's inconsistent with the choice for XOR)

the notation for the gates are inspired from standard ones. you can have a look here : https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_gate#Symbols But since some symbols are not ASCII-7 compliants I changed them to something close in this regard ( ^ for up arrow for NAND, a long dash for NOR so -, a + in a circle for XOR so +,  XNOR returns true when both inputs are equal so = ).
I considered prefixing the NOTed gates with a ~ but I felt it would make parsing harder. 
If you think it would be either to stick with more computer like symbols ( & | ^ )  and prefixed with ~ for negated ones then I guess it could be done. We would have a special case for NOT which would be a single ~, hence people would have to look at next char for differenciation.

for the switches I introduce them in a specific test so that people can start focusing on parsing and simple logic first.

But indeed brute force is the easiest way of solving this. I'm sure other method are possible and would allow for much more complex circuits (many inputs and switches). But even with brute force you can optimize a bit to stop path that would lead to a longer solution that the current best one, since order of toggling has no impact on solution.

Maybe for an harder version of this with more than 2 inputs for gates, and more than 2 outputs for switches.
as for using A O X and a o x for gates I would say yes. characters themselves are not important, it's their meaning that count ;-)
Thanks for your advise, I have updated the puzzle as per.

Don't know what the previous I/O format, but if you want reliability with that sort of input I'd suggest simply giving a figure for H, and specifying in the constraints that W is always less than... looks like 26 in your case, but you can make it larger for safety.

This lets you have legitimate variable-length lines, which is not something you're actively looking for (yours currently look perfect), but something that will avoid complaints down the road when the puzzle's been approved and edited by careless moderators.
I'm not aware of a language where it would be much harder to read in.

before it was variable length lines with an *EOF* marker on the last line. Actually this could required a 2 pass reading if you cannot allocate arrays dynamically.

PS : I have updated the stub generator accordingly
